block.p: Gore Ally as Target The new president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America has given Al Gore a fund-raising advantage and given the Republicans a ready campaign target.
PAGE 30
Gore Ally as Target The new president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America has given Al Gore a fund-raising advantage and given the Republicans a ready campaign target.
PAGE 30
Criticism on Iran Inquiry A bipartisan panel says the United States has not pressed Iran enough in its inquiry into a 1996 bombing that killed 19 servicemen.
PAGE 6
Ex-Treasury Secretary Dies William E. Simon, who led the energy office and the Treasury Department under President Richard M. Nixon, died at 72.
PAGE 44
Devils Take 2-1 Lead The Devils' top line scored both goals in a 2-1 victory over the defending champion Dallas Stars in the Stanley Cup finals.
SPORTSSUNDAY

New England's Variety Choose a tempo: On Moosehead Lake in Maine, two's a crowd, while the Monadnock region mixes diversion with isolation. Williamstown hums with culture of all kinds, and Burlington goes all out with jazz and Mozart. And Plymouth Notch? Calvin Coolidge lived there -- enough said. Also: Fine dining doesn't stop at Boston's city limits.
TRAVEL

Unburied Treasures Archaeologists in Turkey frantically continue the effort to rescue Roman art treasures before the rising water behind a new dam on the Euphrates River engulfs the ruins of the ancient city of Zeugma.
MAGAZINE

Summer Reading A special issue of the Book Review, with roundups on travel by Karen Karbo, cooking by Thomas McNamee and gardening by Verlyn Klinkenborg; and the editors' selection of some 160 notable books of this season so far.
BOOK REVIEW
The Broadway Season The best plays, like ''True West,'' ''Copenhagen'' and ''Dirty Blonde,'' offer glimpses into other lives.
ARTS & LEISURE
What Worries Americans A hot new issue is lurking just below the political radar.
WEEK IN REVIEW

Internet, or Pie, in the Sky Craig O. McCaw, the first cellular phone tycoon, has made big long-shot communications bets pay off. But a host of questions surround his most ambitious yet: a $10 billion plan to deliver the Internet everywhere on Earth by satellite.
MONEY & BUSINESS
